I spend my day (in vaj/wsad) writing small test snippets in a 
workspace which answer a result which I open in an inspector. For 
these tests, success is measured by what I see in the inspector. But 
storing these tests in junit has independent value. For one, success 
can also defined as 'no exception thrown', which is what 
junit would test. (The exception might be an unanticipated error, or 
a runtime exception I deliberately throw in the test). The other is 
simply the value of 'cataloging' and sharing these tests rather than 
having them ad hoc in a development workspace. True, I dont *have* to 
use junit for that but it fits (except for the return value issue I 
am raising).

Obviously I can wrapper my test methods in a junit method but it is a 
waste of time. 

Also thanks to Mike for the tip about looking at the code, great 
idea. But I dont have any source for junit.jar in the junit3.8.1.zip 
file I downloaded from junit.org (also sourceforge), else I'd have 
fixed this myself. Where do I find the source distro?

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Wenner <robert@p...> wrote:
> On Monday 23 June 2003 18:43, areider wrote:
> > I would like to write test methods that I can reuse outside of 
junit,
> > where I would want to inspect the result of the test. Right now 
I'm
> > faced with writing the methods twice.
> 
> The result of the test would be "nothing happens" if it passes or 
an 
> exception if not. 
> Does that suffice?
> If not, what else do you want to do with the "test result"?
> 
> Robert
